pros: Fitness benefits, flexible schedule, working with like-minded people
cons: competitive, hard to advance in the company ladder, unrealistic expectations of a retail employee

headline: Store Manager
pros: At its best, the company offered personal development to young women (and men of course) and taught valuable skills for later careers. The discount on apparel was also nice, as was the stipend for fitness classes.
cons: Created an environment where you were at times set up to fail and had no support because of the culture of extreme personal responsibility - employees were always pushed to take responsibility and accountability while upper management and company policy never did. The scope and breadth of some of the job responsibilities for one person was at times breathtaking. In-store jobs are not friendly to those with later-stage life needs (children, solid benefits, salary that supports a stable life in San Francisco) and corporate jobs are hard to come by, even for those with the company for years and years.

headline: Educator
pros: Absolutely incredible Staff to work with. The company invests a lot of time and money into their employees- great benefits and perks.
cons: Should have separate roles for social media and community at each store

headline: Great products and great culture.
pros: Company has great values and very team oriented. Everyone sets goals and creates a support system. Free group fitness classes.
cons: Mandatory to work one weekend day minimum. Very difficult to change shifts with coworkers or request time off.

headline: Working here is like repeatedly smashing your head into a brick wall, a really really pretty one.
pros:
Sweat sessions paid by company
Decent compensation when commissioning 
An alternative retail concept
The clothes are high quality and the design is fresh and well thought
cons: Management is unprofessional and the workplace is full of cliques. The management team will insist you work on doing a job aspect in the approved way and then will not do so themselves. There's a lot of self importance and big fake egos going on. To me, there's nothing worse than working at a company that constantly harps on being mindful and including but does no such thing.

headline: Better than working at most retail stores, but still a retail job.
pros:
Pros- fitness benefit
Staff discount 
Relatively easy job
Fun people to work with
cons:
Cons- still a low paying retail job, where I'm expected to do much more than a regular retail job for pretty much the same pay.
Little room for growth within the store 
( seems like you have to jump through burning hoops to become a key leader)

headline: I love working here.  The people are great and there's a lot of opportunity for growth.
pros: Work life balance is a high priority.
cons: Low wage for part-time employees.

headline: Great Place
pros: Fun, healthy, great community, goal oriented
cons: time commitment, on your feet all day

headline: good bad and ugly
pros: discounts, fun people, atmosphere, customers, workouts
cons: salary, managers, organization, lack of communication, terrible

headline: great culture, if carried out authentically by the particular leadership team
pros: health and fitness centered, culture of positivity and personal development. entrepreneurial environment
cons: each store is given a lot of room to run their business as it sees fit, leaving it open to weakness if the leadership is weak

headline: Educator
pros:
yoga benefit
personal development
skill in: sales, brand strategy, community engagement
caring team
strong management
cons: retail hours, but that comes with the territory

headline: Would recommend.
pros:
atmosphere; coworkers
Great culture, fun place to work
I would recommend it to my friends. Fast-paced, most of my coworkers share the company's values & live a healthy lifestyle
cons: management- Managers could give better feedback and be more organized. Communication all levels can be improved. Managers should give employees more freedom and leverage  to control their own projects.

headline: Happy I worked there - will always prefer to hire someone who worked for lululemon
pros: Extensive training, lots of personal development, fun yet professional environment, I have learned so much about customer service and business management. It is the only company I would work for in the retail world. Salary is higher than other retail companies.
cons: The company is very demanding - as soon as you raise to the Key Leader position you are required to work a lot more than the hours "on the clock"

headline: fun for a time
pros: discounts on great clothes, easy work, can be a fun environment depending on your manager, focus on personal as well as professional development
cons: have to 'drink the kool-aid', work environment can be catty

headline: Fun
pros: Good discount, free yoga classes
cons: There are no cons to a sales job at lulu

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: great work life balance, challenging environment, and entrepreneurship mentality.
cons: none come to mind at this moment.

headline: I had a positive experience that is atypical for most retail jobs.
pros: Company culture, fellow employees, personal growth, discount on products
cons: Not many cons... maybe a little too focused on working out as a team

headline: not overly impressed
pros: my friend recommended i work in store after telling me about her benefits, employee discount, comped fitness class and all around good vibes in store. all of the reasons above i do agree with and as far as retail jobs go lululemon was the best.
cons: management expected you to have no life and devote all your time to the store, not an actual "work-life balance". the company claims to be goal oriented but to be blunt management couldn't care less about people who's goals did not consist of working at lululemon forever

headline: pretty good
pros: Very nice people, very flexible dresscode
cons: make you sit on a yoga mat

headline: Amazing place to develop.
pros: Leadership that is concerned with your self-development; amazing work/life balance; great team environment; can be creative with ideas and really run each store as it's own business; a company that gives and receives feedback without taking it personally- really brings yoga philosophy to the business; amazing discount
cons: Sometimes the culture can seem fake or off-putting; compensation does not always match the amount of work and hours your expected to put in; never suppose to hit overtime, but have projects that require it- work for free so as not to violate work/life balance; all substantial career opportunities are in Vancouver.

headline: Great company to work for to establish and build upon your goals.
pros: Goal-setting and gives you a course for how you want your life to be, the people you work with are like-minded and fun, the job itself is fun and the guests are generally great. You can also generally be able to move to any store in the country and work there which is great if you need to move or want to make a life change.
cons: It may take awhile to get used to the lululemon culture, meaning you have to be able to give and receive feedback and give straight talk to everyone you work with.

headline: pt time for 11/2 yrs.
pros: Upbeat, fun and health- oriented workspace.
cons:
Too much focus on feedback. We were
Encouraged to give others feedback and at times I felt pressured to find something negative about coworkers in order to help in their "development." Working  Weekends were a drawback

headline: great experience and great people
pros: perks: free workout classes and great discount on clothing
cons: There are many pointless emails and meetings that seem to just be a check list and not anything worthwhile.

headline: Merchandising
pros: Great people, positive work environment, a real sense of goal setting and development (depending on team) plus the free workouts are great (don't need a gym membership)
cons: Not so much a "con" but right now most teams are thinly stretched due to lack of bandwidth, but management are hiring in a big way to fill the gaps. So longer than standard 9-5 hours are pretty normal.

headline: Fun. But maybe too much.
pros: Onsite gym, free fitness classes, good discount, provides  leadership tools.
cons: Ever changing hours , young inexperienced managers, too many screw around meetings (which make your work day longer).

headline: the good, the bad, and the brutal
pros: you get to work with other yoga people, which is great because you get to know so much of your community. you also get a discount, which helps if you are are yogi, crossfit runner, or yoga teacher. the majority of people at your store are usually inspiring and awesome.
cons: whatever the company is doing at their headquarters is totally different than what happens at the store. they are in serious denial about what it is like to work on the ground. they say they want feedback, but if you actually give it, they don't really want to hear it, or you get in trouble. they celebrate themselves constantly, but where are the real benefits? the company is endlessly focused on "pipeline" and "successors" and making lululemon a career... except they pay on the very low spectrum of retail pay, especially for what is asked of you. if you think you're going to move from a store level to a corporate level, that's a joke. there is almost no movement from store to the SSC, because the upper echelon makes it really clear that your value is only in speaking well about the company, and you are definitely a looking down upon. regional managers talk down to you and barely get to know you. they are not in reality about the fact that poor pay, no growth, disrespect and placating teams with empty promises does not a career make. nor does it make a business worth committing yourself to... especially when you are going to be working all hours of the day and night, working without getting paid, and never seeing any real changes made above the store level.

headline: KeyLeader
pros: Great Health/Workout access and really great environment at first. They hire some cool people- friends for life.
cons: Typical corporate company: feels like a sorority with passive aggressive techniques from upper management, using lingo as a double edge sword. Not all lululemon stores have this environment but they use goals as form of promotion. Interview process within company is unprofessional and manager uses schedule against people.

headline: so fun!
pros: work, life balance, and FEEDBACK! it's an awesome place
cons: sometimes feedback got too intense

headline: Challenge.  Creativity.  Personal Development.  Sweat Life.
pros:
-constant personal development
-live and breathe 'sweat once a day' manifesto
-challenges you to see beyond what's realistic and go after things you never thought possible
-the connection within the community is amazing; meet so many inspiring, talented people
-supportive community within the team
cons:
-always striving for something more can be hard
-forward thinking company with high expectations, however financial compensation doesn't always match this

headline: Culty
pros: Got to workout and do yoga for free. Decent pay for retail. Good discount on their clothes. Meet some interesting individuals.
cons: It was a very gossipy environment. It was also catty and faux inspirational. They basically wanted you to believe that you could change the world with their yoga pants; further, you had to repeat that message to the customers. Basically drink the kool-aid or get fired.

headline: great work enviornment, very supportive, fun
pros: lots of fun, great people
cons: can be too heavily focused on feedback

headline: The chance to work in a dynamic environment with fantastic people.
pros: Awesome employee benefits- yoga and fitness classes, personal development and vision & goal coaching.  Managers that invest in their people and create opportunities for growth.
cons: It's still a retails business and there are times when being on the sales floor can be challenging.

headline: Fun people, management can be hard
pros: Fun environment, co workers have a great attitude, 60% discount on all items if full time 40% if part time
cons: It easy for people to get their way. You are not allowed to talk about other coworkers so if they are doing something wrong and deny it, your out of luck.

headline: lululemon opens all kinds of doors!
pros: It's amazing how things just fall into your life - that happened with me and lululemon. Working for this athletic clothing company has not only helped me cultivate my management skills but it has opened all kinds of doors in my personal life. Every day I am given the opportunity to be creative and jump into my own personal development. Not to mention, I work with some of the greatest people I have ever met!
cons: There are no cons when you get to sweat every day!

headline: Working at the SSC or Head Office
pros:
Unbelievable on-boarding and training program. 
Hiring experience was great!
Competitive salary and extra perks are good (free weekly workouts, product discount).
They invest in your personal and professional development in a real way.
There is lots of room to move laterally or up. High-growth and fun environment.
Offices have been up-graded since I left and are now much nicer.
cons:
Benefits philosophy is that "athletes don't get sick" and is reflected in the bare minimum coverage for massage, Physio, acupuncture, etc. but who needs those things more than athletes??

Open plan offices have been proven to negatively impact productivity and this whole building is open plan. Headphones are a must!

headline: Cult-Like Company, Condescending Management
pros:
-Huge Employee Discounts
-Make new friends
-Workout Riembursments
-God place to find yourself as a person
cons:
-Management isn't really interested in "listening"
- Work Life balance only matters if it's a part of the surrounding community
-Management is condescending
-Everyone wants to be in authority because of the way everything is structured
-Constant back chatter among the employees and management
-Putdowns
-Unreasonable write ups
-Lack of Communication

In this company everyone is made responsible for themselves, in which most of the time it's used against you.

headline: Great Experience Overall
pros: great culture, get to work with like-minded fitness enthusiasts.
cons: lots of turnover, not much control over hours (or lack thereof)

headline: Great company
pros: Great experience.  Fun culture.
cons: Retail politics. Advancement is totally internal which makes it hard for new qualified people to get appropriate positions.

headline: Lots of perks, fake yoga culture
pros: Lots of perks like yoga, free classes
cons: Very high level, drinking the "koolaid", singular culture

headline: Key Leader
pros:
work/play attitude and balance
office culture
great product
companys want for you to excel and be the best you
cons: Sometimes the "open" attitude could be a bit much, but holding each other responsible elevates the entire team.  Very few cons.

headline: Working for lululemon athletica has been very great experience and opened my eyes to a whole new lifestyle and culture.
pros: Health benefits, free fitness classes, goal setting, leadership workshops, facilities, location, great people and conversation.
cons: The base salary starts quite low, and it takes a lot of time and effort to move up a pay bracket. Long work hours, and sometimes co-workers are a bit full on.

headline: great company culture. chaotic working style
pros: company culture, management relationships with employees
cons: chaotic work environment, can innovate way more

headline: Cult-like Environment
pros: Decent health benefits, yoga classes paid for, quality merchandise
cons: Lack of communication, unorganized upper management that lack experience, constant negative feedback dressed up as being "helpful" and "supportive". Constantly pushed to take part in what they call a "wellness program" called Landmark which in actuality is a cult-like pyramid scheme with an overall negative perspective of human interactions.

headline: Working with this company has fueled personal and professional growth in myself and others.
pros: It is inspiring, encouraging, fun, and we all live healthful, fit lives.
cons: Typical retail cons- working holidays, long hours, lots of folding, etc.

headline: I love working for a company that takes care of their employees. I never thought I would love "retail".
pros:
The company cares about who you are as an individual and what your vision and goals look like. You are held accountable for taking those steps necessary to reach your 1 year, 5 year, and 10 year goals. They truly care about where you are going and where you want to be, even if it isn't a permanent future with Lululemon. 

One of my favorite things is the "illegal" backroom conversations. Talking about a team member behind their back is not allowed. I was hesitant to work for a store that was 90% female coworkers because I don't like the caddy-ness that happens when girls spend too much time together. However, at Lululemon, you are held accountable for giving, what we call, Feedback, whether it is positive or constructive. It helps to know that you have the ability to give your peers feedback, but the greatest thing is that you have the ability, and are encouraged, to give feedback to your managers and leadership team. It is an empowering company to work for without a doubt.
cons: The blackout period from December 15-January 15 for holiday shopping. You aren't allowed to request a single day off in that month long period. With that said, you won't work any more hours than you would in the normal scheduling period, but you can't request specific days off.

headline: Major Market / HV Store Manager
pros:
-The Brands Equity (even with a few bumps in the road we have a pretty killer reputation)
-The people
-The perks (hello super fair pay and complimentary fitness)
-The business philosophy (an org that truly values innovation and trying new things and listening to their people). 
-We are encouraged to only work 40 hours a week and they actually mean it!
-Paying more at the sales associate (educator) level means we get to hire smarter/higher quality individuals resulting in development of people who actually stay!
-If you work hard, you are given plenty of opportunities to grow and move up
cons:
-Some procedures need to be level set with the best ways of doing things in retail. Sometimes we try to do thing differently just for the sake of being different and it doesn't work out great.
-no 401k plan
-Business acumen/talent level (SM's, RM's & AD's) is kindve all over the place in leaders because it was formerly not a priority, culture was the only priority. It would be helpful to level set this. New CEO seems to be a great balance of business and culture, hopefully that trickles down.
-no 401k plan

headline: The best retail job.
pros: Everyone is so friendly. The work environment is so casual and relaxed, while still remaining professional. Company pays for you to workout. Nice daily bonus and quarterly bonus system.  Good discount.
cons: Typical retail cons such as dealing with snooty customers and being on your feet most of the day. Short breaks.

headline: Culture, Balance, and Perks
pros:
- great perks: yoga/fitness class anywhere in the community paid for 2x/week, great clothing discount, in-house yoga and fitness classes every day with beautiful changerooms to use
- standard hours and overtime expectations low to non-existent; lots of flexibility with hours worked too
- culture is amazing:  education is at the heart of everything we do and there are numerous opportunities to take advantage of self-development and leadership resources
cons: - lower salary than other business for comparable roles

headline: #joblove
pros: what an incredible place to work!  I am happy every day to come to work and hang out with people who are up to big things....in their work and personal lives.  the opportunities here are endless and i am inspired every day.
cons: the parking lot fills up by 8:30....wait, there is free parking??  Ok, so that is a pro!

headline: Fantastic company!
pros: This company is a real & authentic as its people. Very rare! In fact, in my more than 20 years being in the work world, I have never seen or heard of a company who supports their people more to grow & develop into great leaders. Its also a super fun place to work and the work culture is awesome! Like the 7 limbs of yoga ;-)
cons: This company lives it's values every day. It's goals may seem altruistic & audacious but they are committed to making them come true. Compensation is good too & with bonus it can be very good. I have nothing negative to say about lulu.

headline: Strong focus on culture and community
pros: Great discounts on merchandise, great perks for community fitness classes, and well laid-out hiring/training process
cons: Often teams are young and inexperienced, which sometimes results in managerial incompetency

headline: Overall Positive Experience
pros: Positive work environment, great to work with motivating and goal-oriented people everyday.  Everyone in my store is really good friends, so we work out and go out together outside of the store setting.  Perks: company pays for employees to work out pretty much anywhere in the community, the discount on merchandise is very generous, and the commission system allows for employees to make a great deal more than base pay when the store does well.  Opportunity for growth if you are willing to dedicate a lot of time to it.
cons: Company puts big emphasis on work-life balance, but sometimes doesn't live up to that.  Projects are often expected to be done when there isn't time during shifts to do them, so I end up doing them on my own time.  Additionally, requesting time off can be a pain, as my store made us use a vacation day if any change in availability on the weekend was made.  Lastly, the company only offers a job-protected maternity leave if you worked a certain number of hours within 12 months before leave.  Despite having worked full-time for the company for the better part of 4 years, I was not guaranteed my job back because I was finishing my degree while working part-time for several of the months during my pregnancy, so I had to resign and then apply back after my leave.

headline: Opportunities if you look for them!
pros: Work life balance, great people on a personal level, down to earth yet focused on achieving store and personal goals. Benefits if you lead an active lifestyle. Hint, yoga!
cons: On your feet a lot, but what retail job isn't!

headline: Great Company
pros: This company really emphasizes goal-setting in everything that they do, which I found to be very interesting. The free workouts are also a huge plus, alongside the major discount that they give their full-time employees.
cons: Hours, Closing shifts, Management schedules you for weird hours/days-off, Everyone has to work weekends

headline: All about culture
pros: Lots of great professional, goal development here, but it depends store to store, and certain locations it can feel a bit more sterile or less organic. Fun folks to work with and the work is relatively easy.
cons: It's very all inclusive lifestyle here and people hang out and sweat outside of work together a lot. Some people may not enjoy this.

headline: lululemon is one of the best companies/retailers to work for in the world!
pros:
lululemon truly cares and focuses attention on it's people - we are given the opportunity to grow and develop both personally and professionally
lululemon offers great benefits included fitness classes - I have never been in better shape in my life and lululemon not only supports but they promote this healthy living
Everyday I get to have fun and work with a team I love
lululemon has a unique culture that encourages healthy living, having fun and being an entrepreneur
cons: No cons that I can think of only pros

headline: Couldnt ask for a better job and company
pros:
Everyone is motivating and wonderful. It is like one big family. I have been working here for just over a year. People will pass me on the stairs and say good morning or ask how I am. People who work here have come from different places both location wise and company. It is cool to work with so many diverse awesome people. 
The company offers opportunity and devevelopment.
The company is growing and it is awesome to contribute to the growth. I love spending time in the stores and connecting with our guest. I look forward to coming to work every day!
cons: I have no cons here

headline: Amazing, fun, hilarious place to work
pros: yoga studio, gym in the office, open plan working environment, fun stuff always happening, so much wealth in the area of personal develpoment and growth
cons: due to the fast growth of the business, some procedures are lacking and we are catching up in implementing systems that serve the needs

headline: culture experts at lululemon
pros: amazing company culture, inspiring colleagues, ability to influence, developmental opportunities, transparency, opportunity for growth, and LOTS of yoga and athletics.
cons: NA- if you're already passionate about athletics and development- it's an incredible culture!

headline: lots of on-call shifts
pros: easy job, not rocket science. laid-back atmosphere for the most part.
cons: can't use your employee discount because, well, you work retail! no extra money to spend on fancy workout clothes even with the discount. seasonal employees are given lots of on-call shifts that are hardly ever used, meaning you barely work some weeks.

headline: Amazing culture and development
pros: love coming to work everyday, never dread sunday nights.  Everyone here is super supportive of personal and career goals and genuinely want to help you acheive them. Leadership is the best I have experienced - they are supportive and collaborative and let you try new projects and be innovative and entrepreneurial. The fitness benefits, bonus, rrsp matching and merit increases are awesome perks.  They truly care about their employees and they have fun events each month for us to enjoy and have fun together.
cons: can't really think of anything- things move fast here and its very innovative - so best for people who like being in fast paced environments

headline: Changing the industry...
pros: I love lululemon because the values and philosophy of the organization are aligned with mine. The company is purpose driven, and truly cares about positively impacting people's lives (both inside the company and in the community).
cons: Very fast paced and entrepreneurial... for some people they will find that there is a lack of "structure" and rules. Not the best place for someone if they value hierarchy and want to feel like they have control.

headline: amazing people and culture
pros: people location fun challenging culture
cons: hours pay rate outdated store

headline: We are not given the proper tools to succeed in our job roles.
pros: There are great benefits to working at lululemon athletica such as weekly fitness classes that are paid by the company, great discounts and encouraging each individual to dive into their goal setting and look at their long term goals.
cons: The pay is quite low in comparison to other call centre companies and even though lululemon advocates about work-life balance- this isn't really the case when it comes down to it. Leadership is extremely strict about time-off even if you've been in a traumatic life event or an accident. Furthermore, we aren't given the tools to succeed when it comes down to helping our guests with online orders. The system that lululemon uses for online transactions is extremely out-dated, there's always system glitches, unknown cancelled orders, duplicated orders and we can't cancel or edit individual orders.

headline: Fun, goal setting environment
pros: Flexible schedule, free workouts, great discount
cons: management can make or break your experience, work-life balance can be tough

headline: Great people, horrible job hours/ management.
pros: People I worked with are wonderful. Great entry level / transition job. The focus on fitness and "sweating together" with fellow educators are great and absolutely my favorite part of lululemon. Discounts are great, but that's basically where your pay cheque would go.
cons: Even though we are encouraged to have fitness in our routine, it is hard to find time to do so between shifts and everything else in life. Low pay for job nature (worked outside of stores). I still to this day do not know who my direct manager is.

headline: !Amazing company to work for!
pros: The company culture is incredible. The work life balance can't be beat. I keep going back! Salary is decent for retail and bonuses come in handy. Plus, the discount helps.
cons: It's retail, so schedule always comes into play. You have to have a flexible schedule to get the position and holiday can be pretty grueling. As always, the quality of work depends on the manager.

headline: Great company in North America/Canada, not in Asia
pros: Company culture is unique and very embedded throughout its people and product. Employees are encouraged to goal -set and strive for a 10-year vision of what their life could be. Building out showrooms in Asia required a lot of Community work, which meant building close relationships with fitness and yoga studio owners and clients. Definite perk if you enjoy fitness with two complimentary classes a week on the company.
cons: In Asia, teams are small and often overworked. Expectations are grandiose and seem attainable, but instructions on how to carry through are unclear. The original company culture is sometimes forgotten and shunned in favour of creating more sales in retail instead.

headline: inauthentic, chaotic and poorly managed
pros: Their hiring promises attract some really great people, even though most don't stay
cons:
Image of progressive company isn't reflected in reality
Poor management results in chaotic environment and high turnover
Severance clauses in contracts enable poor treatment of employees

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Being around like minded people and working next to smart, talented people.  Working in an environment where you are supported and challenged to achieve goals, both personally and professionally.  Great fitness benefits.
cons: Most people like myself were attracted to the brand for our similar fitness/yoga/goal setting  lifestyle.  You have to be good about drawing boundaries with this job.  It's easy for the lines to be blurred about when work ends and personal life begins.

headline: Educator
pros: Great culture and people.
cons: Very demanding of your time outside of work schedule.

headline: lululemon is an amazing and exciting place to work.
pros: Flexible hours, competitive pay, welcoming environment, personal growth
cons: Honestly I had no con's working here, I loved it!

headline: Needs improvement
pros:
-reimbursed fitness classes
- discount
- fun place to work
cons:
-Lack of training, and then you are at fault for not knowing key ideals from the training 
- they encourage you to take initiative but you are very often told no and you are stopped in your tracks
- can get very caddy
- push people out instead of having open talks

headline: Big promises, bigger letdown
pros: The people are great but there's lots of talk and not much walk with the leadership. free classes are great. discount ok but don't count of getting it for your spouse.
cons: Work Life Balance is a myth, especially on the design floor. Don't be surprised if you are asked to work through the weekend or on holidays.  Half the work is getting through broken processes and the rest if just to catch up. Much of the upper management does not come from experience but rather from just being at lululemon for so many years - old & out of touch. Expectations vary greatly depending on who's managing. Too many random initiatives going on at once.

headline: East Coast Manager
pros: Innovative and fun company. Great product.
cons: Upper management isn't in the same page. From week to week it varied with regional and corporate leaders. Conflicting leadership makes it difficult to run a store with confidence. A bit of entitled attitudes from those in Vancouver and those now working on the East Coast from the corporate office. You must oblige to all development plans and say yes or you will be an outcast and never promoted.

headline: Fun place to be
pros: great discount, paid for workout classes, fun group of coworkers
cons: it is retail after all… shifts can get boring.

headline: Great company, poor pay
pros: Fun environment, free workouts, community involvement, nice co-workers, you wear awesome workout clothes to work, room for growth, great managers
cons: really low pay, on your feet for hours, not mentally challenging, no benefits until full-time, hard work/life balance because you have to work weekends

headline: Disappointment
pros: Coming from an entrepreneurial background I loved that each store is run on a 'boutique' level.  I was able to be involved in many different aspects of running the business such as: visual merchandising, social media (facebook), event planning, networking, designing marketing collateral, etc.
cons:
The pay is simply not enough to support yourself in NYC.
The culture of the business absolutely differs from store to store and the store manager absolutely sets the tone.  I was not fairly recognized or celebrated for all the hard work and time that I put into my job.  It was my pleasure to work 'off the clock' because I was passionate about what I was doing and believed that I was with a company that wanted me to grow and develop.  I truly believed that one day it would all work out in my favor.  This did not happen.

headline: has changed my life in the most amazing way
pros: reaching goals you never thought you could do, meeting amazing people who have such a positive affect on your life
cons: tiring being on your feet all day and being full of energy, 30 minute lunch breaks

headline: I've had an amazing experience working for this company and am intending to grow within it.
pros: I love the way the company is supportive of your individual goals both personal and professional. There is a focus on work/life balance and direct communication which I feel is lacking in other places of employment.
cons: I honestly do not have any personally negative experiences with the company.

headline: Best Company
pros: great company culture, work-life balance and leadership
cons: retails industry hours.. work weekends and holidays.

headline: Best job I've ever had
pros:
-Really great pay for a retail job

Meanwhile, dominating, hypocritical, and superficial employees were promoted quickly. Also, the opportunity for growth with the company was grossly misrepresented. All of the above was an unfortunate discovery for those who signed on because they they thought it would be a yogic environment filled with opportunity; especially given that most of the people I knew there had taken HUGE pay cuts to be there. headline: worthwhile, however choose your path wisely
pros: Some of the people at this company are absolutely fantastic individuals and remain some of my closest friends. The focus that is given during your first 6 months here can really help build a strong sense of self and realization of one's goals in life way beyond your time at the company. Especially for the younger staff I worked with the reward of watching their personal growth happen in a relatively short period of time was my most fulfilling memory of my employment here.  Meeting and working out with some of the best instructors in my city was also a highlight and the health care package includes complimentary workouts at any studio. I highly advise anyone who thinks they are interested in the company to work for a contract seasonal position to see if it's a good fit.
cons: The culture is appealing for sure, however over time it can become exhausting, diminished and hypocritical.  Being a member of management made longevity here really taxing as you were expected to give 150% of yourself, your time and energy as a base line to be considered a "good employee". The concept of "worklife balance" is spoken of but too often forgotten about. Upper management is very disconnected from what happens at a store level. Don't expect to have much privacy about your life here, you wanting to keep anything private is considered holding you back from your own development. Vacation time or days off are difficult and I found that the only way to have control over my life balance was to have a group of employees that had each other's backs and would barter coverage when needed (I got you if you get me this day). Compensation is hourly with enhancement of team commission for most positions, how well you do depends mostly on the success of the store location and  organization of management. At times you will be pressured into incorporating many workouts at many locations all over your city and that at times can be very stressful and tiring. The quality of the product at times was in question and as a team we were told to keep it under wraps- that rode on my conscious and made me question the moral fiber of the company as a whole.

headline: Great Company

headline: Good experience
pros: Based on how the store does, you earn a daily & monthly bonus -- it's a team bonus so it takes out the cut-throat mentality of most sales positions. They pay for your workouts, provide you with life-goal coaching. If you want to see change within the company, it's pretty easy to get ahold of who you need to talk to up at corporate , but seeing changes made from your feedback is a completely different story (might not ever happen). We do talk with the designers once a month to give them guest product feedback, but who knows it if they actually listen.
cons: I know some people that are Educators for 2+ years PART TIME and are never offered fulltime status, even if they have been promised it by management. Product quality has really gone down the toilet over the past year or so , so it's hard to stand by a brand that isn't 100% transparent. If you have any plans of working for corporate, your best bet is to go somewhere else to get experience (especially if it's specialized) and then come back and apply for jobs at corporate. It's next to impossible to start as an Educator and move up to corporate without having to put up with years of BS and become a Key Leader, ASM, and SM first. Very frustrating.

headline: If you want an excellent example of trying to move up in a company and failing...
pros: My coworkers were wonderful people, and free yoga! Personal and professional development was good, though the Landmark Forum is COMPLETELY NUTS.
cons: Trying to move up in the company. I have 2 higher degrees (BA and MA) in a field that would allow me to move up in any apparel company, and it was my dream to work in HQ at lulu. But for some reason I wasn't able. I financed a trip myself to canada and visited/shadowed the team I wanted to eventually be on, networked, sent emails, communicated with my store manager, applied to the position I wanted, etc. I was part time at lulu & had a 2nd job relevant to my eventual dream job, but always expressed a desire to become full time at lulu on the store level in an effort to eventually move up to my dream job there. After a year and a half in this situation, I couldn't even even achieve full time status in the store; in fact, there were newer employees than I that were given full time status before me. I GAVE UP and now work in HQ at a different apparel company. Looking back, it's hard to fight the feeling that I wasted a year and a half working there for nothing...

headline: Great Ideas, Horrible Practice
pros: It was enjoyable to work with fellow educators because I felt we were all of a similar mindset: goal oriented, fitness loving, fun, etc. The perks they offered us were nice as well, such as the gym classes and the discount at their stores.
cons:
Unfortunately, the pros do not outweigh the cons; though I never had a problem dealing with employees at my level, once you moved up to the next rung there were serious issues. There's no accountability in terms of what the key leaders or assistant managers might be doing that you have a problem with (very "who watches the watchmen" sort of deal). Like many have said here, most - if not all - of your managers are in their mid-20s and it shows. They tout work-life balance as something that they strive for, but honestly, if you're not showing your face and making your presence known/chumming it with upper management, you will be cast aside. Many people felt that hours were given based on preferential treatment, and not on actual needs as displayed by the employees. Compensation, though higher than the average rate, was still very little, and with such volatility in how many hours you might be receiving, it was often stressful not knowing how much income you might actually be receiving. Furthermore, they expected you to often come much earlier than your shift, which is understandable; however, receiving negative "feedback" for arriving not early enough by their standards was difficult to comprehend, especially when many people could not sustain a living simply by working at Lululemon, and required other forms of employment to maintain an adequate standard of living. 
Power plays were definitely a thing here, and that might come from the fact that management was just a couple years older than the average educator. This became especially apparent when after working under various managers; because no one was in charge of the managers, often working under one of their shifts meant that you would do things their way, which often undermined the work of another manager. But it didn't matter, because there was no one there to hold them accountable for their actions. Innovation, like the work-life balance, was constantly encouraged, so long as you didn't annoy anyone in management. Finally, as many other have said here, management constantly doled out what they termed "feedback", which more often than not felt like a way for them to undermine your work and/or paint you as a bad employee. If there was something that they didn't particularly like that you did, they would make sure to make a note of it so that other managers could see your "shortcomings". In the end, there was not much wiggle room for the creativity that they talked about so freely; it was often best to put your head down, make few suggestions, and do the task at hand (or, if the store was empty and there was nothing to do, pretend that you were doing something).
This is all unfortunate, because although I did enjoy my time there as a whole, it became very apparent that unless I wasn't completely willing to bow down to the culture and drink the Lulu Kool-Aid, then I would forever be considered an outsider.

headline: Lululemon is fun if you need something for the time being but as a career forget it.
pros: They pay for you to workout and you meet a ton of people.  It's a great launching pad because you will be thrown into a crazy network of people not to mention get to know many wealthy guests who are regulars at the store.  The culture of the brand is very positive and good for writing down your goals.
cons: Challenges are that it's mostly women who work at the store which can be overwhelming at times.  Depending on your store there can be major drama.  Other things include super clickiness or even personality differences can be an issue of wether or not you can move up to your next role.  If they like you, then you can move up.  Also they document every little thing about you in this book and watch for patterns they want to fix about you.  If you sense that you are not liked by management watch your back because they will write down anything they can in this book and talk about it in there management meetings and then figure out ways they can fire you.

headline: Great experience at Lululemon, but an undertone of insincerity
pros:
Lots of room for creative and implementation of ideas, this translates into great opportunities for leadership
Free fitness classes
Active work environment and support of healthy life style
Well paid considering the job is in retail
If you're healthy, positive, and into self0betterment, you'll find yourself provided by like-minded individuals
cons: Lululemon promotes itself as being very forward-thinking, creative, set your own path, forge your way, set goals, and I guess in the company's words " elevate yourself from mediocrity". HOWEVER, there are many MANY employees, both at the entry and management levels, that have basically learned how to say these things, with no concept of what they actually mean. This results in some pretty ingenious and often outright bizarre interactions with fellow co-workers who have "bought into" rather than genuinely believe in Lululemon's values.

headline: lulu addic

headline: Great people but the culture is failing
pros:
When you are having fun at the SSC, you are having more fun than any other workplace you will ever work in. Ain't not party like a lulu party!
Out of the 900 or so staff, there are a ton of amazing and inspiring people. The ability to leave your desk and go for a run, a yoga class, to the gym or whatever you want and come back to your desk sweaty is incredible.
cons: The benefits are lacking for a company of this size. The pay is on average about 10% less than what you will get at other companies. The workload itself is staggering. While they promote a good work/life balance, there is not much time to actually get out and enjoy the things that they offer. 10 hour days are normal and don't expect to get any thanks for it.

I found this insane coming from a customer service background. Also they are a bit in your face with goals. I had someone asking me daily "what is your goal for today!" and while most my office mates were  like "To get into a inverted crow!" I was like "To not eat McDonalds for lunch," so it could be I just was not a good fit.

headline: Educator
pros: free work out classes in your area, discount on clothes
cons: ooo where to start.. At first it is fun and you do meet some nice people, but then you realize how cultish it is. I worked there as an educator. I worked super hard and was the only member of the staff that got acknowledged in the review by a secret shopper, for being helpful and knowledgeable about the product. A secret shopper is someone from lululemon corporate that comes into the store under cover to rate it... anyways I never got a good employee review after that, never acknowledged by my manager by that, because I didn't drink the lululemon "Kool-aid." If you come to work excited, ready to work hard, and with a good attitude it gets you know where. You have to be that and work on learning to be super fake and tell your manager that you want to go to Landmark someday... Landmark is a weekend retreat away, where you aren't allowed any contact with family and friends, and they pretty much tell you your life is terrible and you are a failure, then they proceed to build you up... weird huh? yea I thought so too.. That's why I never wanted to go....lululemon tends to forget that it is a RETAIL store. They think they are the next Dr. Phil or Oprah or something... it's real weird...

pros: Work with like-minded individuals who are passionate about living life to the fullest. The product is high-performance, and it is fun to try out new activities with your coworkers.

headline: It was a positive experience resulting in personal growth. I felt connected to my coworkers.

headline: Awesome team and amazing work-life balance
pros: A company that invests in your training and development.
cons: There is a very strong and unique culture at lululemon. My specific experience is that I could take and leave what suited me but if you fall outside of the culture completely, you will not be happy there and vice versa.

headline: They aren't rated as a top company to work for for a reason...
pros: free yoga! discount on yoga apparel! ... some pretty funny guests experiences.
cons: Where to begin? If you aren't immature, unprofessional, prepare to be forgotten or if you are any of those prepare to be attacked.  If you  mind your own business and have no desire to move up in the company - good for you! but If you do want to make a name for yourself, a difference within and in the surrounding community, prepare yourself to kiss somebodys behind.  Whose best friend will you be? who will you spend every second outside of work drinking wine with and gossiping with?? haters hate and its the culture.  leadership of self is never ever displayed and consistency and commitments are only made to those that are favored by any management.  Sucks. but its the whole truth - especially since I went to HR, Regional and area manager and they still did nothing until the management team decided to tell their side of the story, only then did they take action. yikes.  I know what the difference is with listening and actually listening and what morally is right and wrong.  Its who you know, not what you do that gets you to your next position. The culture, your goals, you team efforts, your ideas mean nothing unless you have a position of management and a team of followers. Dont be a part of that.

headline: Amazing company to work for. The values that this company holds for it's product and it's employees is incredible.
pros: The culture of this company is by far my favorite aspect. I love being active in the community, sweating with my co-workers, organizing community events, getting to know our guests and ambassadors in their workout environment. The fact that we get classes paid for is so motivating and so fun to try out all of the local classes.  The discount is definitely a bonus, especially if you are full time. And the people who are hired are seriously the best.
cons: The pay is not the greatest but I guess if you're a younger person still living at home, it is actually great pay for a "retail" job. But if you're trying to save money or make a career change while working for an AWESOME company with AWESOME people, then you won't be saving anything.

headline: Great team, a lot of company jargon, and little room for advancement
pros: The people who worked in the store were lovely to work with, the clothes are an easy sell, good pay for managers, free workouts, and each day can be different.
cons: Upper management often isn't aware what's going on at a store level, store atmosphere and expectations vary depending on who's managing, lack of clear store vision, too many initiatives going on at once, and a lot of company jargon when discussing roles. Very difficult to advance.

headline: Daily I am  treated as an asset to the store and the company as a whole.
pros: They value your personal development, they value your life/work balance, and they value and encourage you to set your goals high and to crush them!
cons: The retail hours can be tough, especially around holiday hours but that's to be expected. You may be held accountable for things you are afraid to achieve in life!

headline: Enjoy the people very much.  Management over thinks and makes something that should be simple into a major project.
pros: Energetic, fun people. Workouts are priority, plenty of opportunity to get involved in more than just showing up for a shift
cons: schedule can be grueling, subjective reviews/feedback that leave you unclear, too much jargon, may never use the word "entrepreneur" again in my lifetime.

headline: Educator Review
pros: Family environment, great training, fast growth, constant education, positive environment, free fitness classes, drive to be healthy and live a balanced life, while no peer pressure or negativity towards those who are not as active in the fitness world. Group of individuals that were hired for like mindedness towards healthy lifestyles that creates a wonderful work environment.
cons: Sometimes lack of communication sometimes makes you feel out of the loop with the rest of the team because of only being part time

headline: Backstabbing and two faced management
pros: Great discount on (what used to be) amazing quality clothing
cons:
If you want a repeat of high school, you'll find it here. I was older than most of the other educators AND management, and I was mid twenties, and wow was that made clear! I also have children and was a single mother at the time, going to classes outside of work was pretty close to impossible, and I was constantly being questioned about my lack of commitment. I also didn't feel the 'cheerleader' mold, but in no way am i unfriendly or unapproachable, and found it hard to maintain the constant fake smile I was encouraged to withhold. My manager took it upon herself to hire personal friends and make them key leaders with no experience, over many of us who had worked there for over a year. Management and keyleaders were usually found sitting in our back room or outside of the store gossiping. I was eventually accused of having a bad attitude (which was the same laid back and quiet ('bad') attitude i had for 2 years of employment there. I was written up for a completely vague reason which i never understood. The manager lied to my face when i arranged a meeting with her, telling me she had no idea about my write up or the reason behind it. I was fired days later, with her signature on the paperwork. Lucky me, i was then the unemployed single mother who desperately needed to keep that job, exasperated because i was essentially fired by a clique straight out of Mean Girls. I didnt want to sit with you, anyway.

No wonder this company is going to sh*t.

cons: Completely uneducated and inexperienced management. They are not there for you, they do not care about your well being or advancement. Management is only there to advance themselves. headline: Cult-like atmosphere
pros: Great, active, high energy people with big goals, great discount on merchandise and free workouts, good work-life balance. While on the clock you're encouraged to be creative, chat up peers and customers, and try out the clothes to assist with educating others.
cons: Cult pressure to constantly evaluate yourself and others under the guise of feedback, making you feel less than perfect at all times. Consistent pressure to meet sales goals. Recommended book club readings are actually mandatory.

headline: Great for someone with no life commitments
pros: Generally fun coworkers, great discount, free yoga and workout classes, the pay is decent for retail.
cons: Absolutely NO work/life balance-they want your on personal facebook to be "on brand" and align with their culture. Constantly working nights and weekends...if you are in a relationship or have any kids/pets this is not the place for you!  In general, the store manager has little to no experience or education.  If you are a person with a higher level of education and any amount of street smarts or common sense, you probably won't get along with your manager and definitely will not get promoted.  They also don't like people who like to work their bums off to get ahead...they want people who like to boss others around.  The interview style is a total joke...they don't even do background checks, reference checks, or even look over your resume...

headline: Love Love Love

Love the self development tools such as the CD and books to read from the library, free fitness classes from yoga to crossfit, amazing discount on their clothes and you are surrounded by fitness alike so you are constantly motivated to stay on course - it does get any better than that.
cons: I don't have any cons as I knew what I was signing up for. I think one would have cons if they want something outside of the job description. I strongly believe that a job is what you make it and the vibe here is so positive and encouraging that I can not see how one could not like working here. I have no cons

headline: Growth potential, great fun and culture, good benefits, just choose your store and manager wisely...
pros: Great benefits, young and energetic crowd, great development tools and career possibilities.  A place to learn from mistakes and grow. Staff genuinely cares about guest's experience.  Stores are extremely connected to their community.
cons: Better suited for those athletic and often young and inexperienced individuals who have less financial obligations. A good or bad store manager can make or break your career and experience. Of course, It is your responsibility to make sure you are drawn to the store that is the best fit for you. As a U.S. Citizen, you should research and be very real about your growth potential to corporate. This is a Canadian company and while they have some U.S. based corporate positions, getting permission to work in Canada requires you to be extremely skilled or experienced. This can be limiting to your potential.

headline: Amazing perks but at a high price.
pros: Phenomenal discount, free fitness classes, fun special events, opportunity for travel and leadership training, fast track through management, upbeat, clean and fun work environment.
cons: Little work/life balance, expectation to go 'above and beyond', expectation to read various books and attend events and trainings for which you are not paid, a 'type A'/perfectionist environment that encourages working overtime but doesn't compensate accordingly.  Management at lululemon includes a lot of 'personal development' which is both beneficial and also a negative at times. Employees are held to frequently unattainable standards of 'always being on', 'being bright and shiny', 'giving 110% at all times', 'having high energy at all times', etc. -- these are great standards to have but become quickly suffocating when they're used as catchphrases on a daily basis and are the litmus test for employee effectiveness and contribution.

Fast growth means leanings towards big corporation ways of being. Long decision times and shareholder accountability can make projects and product move slowly - can delay real innovation or early adoption.
Health benefits are lame because founder believes athletes don't have many health issues??? Hello physio?

headline: Some great people, some not so much
pros:
They hire some great people.  All of which get burnt out on the constant hypocrisy and two-faced management.

Commission is decent during the holidays.
cons:
Culture can be very grating. Attempts to be upbeat about clearly unattainable daily goals is transparent and demoralizing to the team.  How about just setting reasonable ones?  Worst part being, the leaders know the educators are not buying that garbage, yet they continue to sweep reality under the rug.   

Performance reviews are often ambiguous with little justification from managers.  Lots of vacuous flowery language with little actual substance constantly regurgitated at every opportunity.  There is a surprisingly large amount of office politics for a retail store.  Didn't know that the extra $2/hr for a key leader position warranted machiavellian tactics among "teammates".  Very cliquey, get chummy with the managers or else you'll be quickly shown the door.  

The much championed gift of feedback only flows downstream.  Constructive feedback given to leaders is often met with defensive and antagonistic responses, stymying development and perpetuating their incompetences.

headline: Great team, great benefits, lack of hours-ivivva
pros: I worked at the ivivva athletica of the lululemon corp. It is basically the same clothes made smaller sizes for girls. The team I was with was very vibrant and constantly interested in everything you were up to. Perhaps a bit too much, but that may be more of a reflection on the people rather than the company. Key leaders made you feel like their equal but with less technical aspects to consider in our position. There were no stuck-up attitudes or  feelings inequality. The benefits were amazing and would benefit anyone who is athletic hence why you have to be athletic to be hired. The interview process was different than others that I have experienced but thorough, they really want to make sure you fit the mold. It was pretty easy to get shifts covered if need be, there were okay modes of communication to make sure that this could get done. Self-development was always encouraged, whether it was reading a book from the knowledge library on leadership or getting experience working in the much busier lululemon.
cons: You have to REALLY be passionate about this job, otherwise spending 8 hours on a slow day with only 3 guests in might be enough to hand in resignation. While it is fun to work on fast-moving days, there are often months of really slow ones and they can be long and tedious. Because lululemon is always hiring, sometimes the location will hire too many people and there will be not enough hours to support everybody therefore somebody gets the boot! The expectation to be bubbly and happy is constantly first and foremost, and you could get a talking-to just for not smiling for a split-second. The other employees at the store sometimes took their job a bit too seriously and fixated on issues and problems that really were not that bad. However, it probably is what keeps them going considering most of the people there plan on making their whole life about working at lululemon.

headline: Very positive, great atmosphere and company culture.
